title: High-flying designer David Caon on the books that keep him grounded
text:
Nicole Abadee Oct 17, 2019 — 12.00am Share

When he's not reimagining aircraft interiors, industrial designer David Caon finds the time to pick up a book or two. The Caon Design Office founder, whose latest project is to refit the interior of Qantas’ A380, speaks with AFR Magazine for its regular What I Am Reading column.

Do you read books for work?

Yes. Something will lead me to a particular architect, designer or artist and then I will search for books about them. I really like the big coffee table design books which give an overview of someone’s career as well as a biographical element.

David Caon: "I am interested in what happens when society breaks down or tries to overregulate itself and a hero rises up to resist."

At the moment I am reading Tom Sachs: Prada Book, an essay collection by Germano Celant and Malcolm Gladwell about Tom Sachs, the American sculptor. I am also reading The Curves of Time, the memoir of Oscar Niemeyer, the Brazilian architect, who is one of my favourite architects.

He talks about his childhood and what he used to do with his friends; it shows he was just a regular guy who enjoyed life – he wasn’t some tortured genius. People can write quite elaborately about their work, but I much prefer hearing about the mundanity of their life because then you can make a connection.

Who are some of your favourite fiction writers?

Haruki Murakami and Kurt Vonnegut. I’ve also been reading a bit of Aldous Huxley. Murakami’s Norwegian Wood is his breakout. With Murakami you never get closure.

He just leaves shit hanging out there and moves on. The Vonnegut books I remember best are Cat’s Cradle and Slaughterhouse Five. I also loved The Catcher in the Rye and Catch-22. They’re classics for a reason.

Why do you like dystopian fiction?

I love stories of the apocalypse and about upside-down societies, like [George Orwell’s] 1984. I am interested in what happens when society breaks down or tries to overregulate itself and a hero rises up to resist. I am talking about books from the ’30s, ’40s and ’50s; it’s interesting how we are still dealing today with many of the issues they were writing about.
description: At work, the creative mind behind the Qantas Dreamliner cabin refit has his head in the clouds. But when reading, he connects with the mundanities of life.
